The Chambers County School System is seeking a Mental Health Service Coordinator. This is a grant-funded position that is available for the 20-21 school year. The MHSC will work with students, families, teachers, and administrators to identify and address the social/emotional,
mental health, and wellness needs of students through collaboration with school-based and community mental health professionals, including school counselors, school social workers, school nurses, school psychologists, and school resource officers. Qualifications must include at least one of the following:
Have a bachelor's degree in social work.
Satisfy ALSDE qualifications for a school counselor.
Satisfy ALSDE qualifications for a school nurse. Previous professional mental health experience or have been licensed in a mental health occupation
including, but not limited to, licensure as a licensed professional counselor (LPC) or marriage and family therapist (MFT).
Other qualifications as determined by the Alabama Department of Mental Health (ADMH) and the ALSDE.
If interested please contact Fran Groover 334-864-9343 ext 10203 and complete an application online with Teach in Alabama.

Five Points Elementary has started off this school year in full force with STEM activities. I visited Ms. Spence's class a few days ago. The students were busy using their Google Chromebooks to complete a variety of activities Ms. Spence had created for them. Technology is a very important part of this classroom. Ms. Spence has also transformed some empty space next door to her classroom to allow students to have room to work on STEM lessons. Student work from the day prior to my visit was displayed on tables. Students were building structures using a variety of materials. They were exploring ways to make their structure the tallest. Blueprints and plans were laid out on the tables. Students were required to think through and design a plan. Then, they were to test the plan and problem solve any areas of need.

I also discovered Ms. Spence was in the process of filling the hydroponics tank. Students will soon be filling the tank with fish and learning how to grow plants without soil - they are learning the hydroponics way.

On Saturday, Phyre (People helping youth reach excellence) hosted the Back to School Bash on the field adjacent to LaFayette High School. Each year they get more creative with their activities for the kids. This year, there was a foam party, laser tag, and the Cyber Game Truck. In addition, there was a variety of games, food and music for all to enjoy. Each school aged child received a generous gift of school supplies as well. So many businesses and individuals help sponsor this event.

The highlight of the day (for me) was a new scholarship opportunity for a senior from LaFayette High School. When the Back to School Bash began seven years ago, there was an MC who really brought a lot of love and energy to the event. His name was Deon Allen. Sadly, he passed away a little over a year ago. One of the things he constantly told his children was he always wanted them to be "generation better". At Saturday's event, a $500.00 scholarship was presented to Marcus Curry. This will become an annual scholarship in Deon's memory to be known as the "Generation Better" scholarship.

To ensure every child and adult's safety on August 21, during the eclipse, we will be dismissing schools 30 minutes later than normal in the eastern time zone schools only. Many schools are having viewings of the eclipse. Students will only be allowed to participate if they have the permission slip returned and have NASA approved eye wear. Be looking for information from your child's school. Because of the cost of the eye wear, some schools will be watching a live stream of the eclipse rather than an outdoor viewing.

During the eclipse no one will be allowed outside of the school building unless they are participating in the viewing. This includes adults and children. This is a safety precaution due to the possibility of eye damage. If you choose to check your child out of school on the 21st, you must do so prior to 1:00 pm central or 2:00 pm eastern. According to NASA officials, the peak of the eclipse will be in our area between 1:34-1:37 central time or 2:34-2:37 eastern time.

More information will be coming!
